results.title: Zoo animals in the wild: crocodiles
results.brief_description: Notes the physical characteristics of crocodiles such as strong jaws, tough skins and powerful tails; and shows the care of baby crocodiles by the mothers. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Zoo animals in the wild: beavers
results.creator_credit: Mel Waskin, Bill Walker and Coronet Films
results.brief_description: Notes the eating habits of the beaver and shows how it constructs a dam using its sharp front teeth to gnaw away branches, and its rudder-shaped tail and webbed back paws to gather mud to cement the branches together. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Zoo animals in the wild: bears
results.creator_credit: Mel Waskin, Bill Walker and Coronet Films
results.brief_description: Points out some of the characteristics of bears such as their strength, their playfulness, and their curiosity as well as their inclination to be solitary animals. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Zoo animals in rhyme
results.brief_description: Amusing rhymes tell us something about zoo animals children love most - the lion, monkey, elephant, kangaroo, giraffe, bear and many others. A basis for storytelling, vocabulary building, rhyme making, and many related activities. Also brings to the class-room elementary science concepts about animal life.

results.title: Zoo
results.brief_description: Visual essay comparing people and animals at a zoo. Using a ‘candid camera’ technique, Haanstra concentrates on commonly shared facial expressions and physical gestures such as eating and sleeping. Accompanied by a jazz music soundtrack but no spoken commentary.
results.description: Visual essay comparing people and animals at a zoo. Using a ‘candid camera’ technique, Haanstra concentrates on commonly shared facial expressions and physical gestures such as eating and sleeping. Accompanied by a jazz music soundtrack but no spoken commentary.

results.title: Zonation
results.creator_credit: H Scales and Sydney Scientific Film Society
results.brief_description: A group of university students study the zonation pattern of animals and plants on a marine rock platform, and the various physical and biological factors contributing to their distribution. At the highest tide level are blue periwinkles; then the barnacle zone, the worm zone and at low tide level, the cunjevoizone and then kelps. The ways in which various creatures protect themselves against dessication from sun and wind and against being washed off the rocks are shown.

results.title: Zoetrope
results.brief_description: Animation device called Zoetrope and assorted animation strips. Body of Zoetrope is a cylinder formation closed on bottom and open at top with a series of slits around top rim and painted green. Wood spindle joins cylinder to metal tiered stand. Zoetrope has five various themed printed paper animation strips depicting illustrations of a sequence of drawings showing motion. Animation strips are either black and white or mono coloured with an animation on both sides.

results.title: Zlateh the Goat
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Winter is late so for Reuven the furrier it is a bad year. After long hesitation he decides to sell Zlateh the goat. However, the pet goat is spared from the butcher’s knife when she saves her young master from a snowstorm.

results.title: Zero, the troublemaker
results.brief_description: Uses animated numerals to show the role of zero in addition and subtraction, and its special use as a place holder for other numerals. Indicates how useful zero can be in both small and large numbers. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Zero de conduite = Zero in conduct (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Banned until 1945, this film has strong ties to surrealist films of the 1920’s. Vigo depicts the oppressive life in a French provincial boarding school and the eventual rebellion by the boys against the authority figures, symbolised in the famous pillow fight, the raising of the flag on the roof, the slow motion procession and the stylised crucifixion of the supervisor. Cinematography by Boris Kaufman, music by Maurice Jaubert.
